    Discovery of a Biased Allosteric Modulator for Cannabinoid 1 Receptor: Preclinical Anti-Glaucoma Efficacy

      Sumanta Garai

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    We apply the magic methyl effect to improve the potency/efficacy of GAT211, the prototypic 2-phenylindole-based cannabinoid type-1 receptor (CB1R) agonist-positive allosteric modulator (ago-PAM). Introducing a methyl group at the α-position of nitro group generated two diastereomers, the greater potency and efficacy of erythro, (±)-9 vs threo, (±)-10 constitutes the first demonstration of diastereoselective CB1R-allosteric modulator interaction. Of the (±)-9 enantiomers, (−)-(S,R)-13 evidenced improved potency over GAT211 as a CB1R ago-PAM, whereas (+)-(R,S)-14 was a CB1R allosteric agonist biased toward G protein- vs β-arrestin1/2-dependent signaling. (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14 were devoid of undesirable side effects (triad test), and (+)-(R,S)-14 reduced intraocular pressure with an unprecedentedly long duration of action in a murine glaucoma model. (−)-(S,R)-13 docked into both a CB1R extracellular PAM and intracellular allosteric-agonist site(s), whereas (+)-(R,S)-14 preferentially engaged only the latter. Exploiting G-protein biased CB1R-allosteric modulation can offer safer therapeutic candidates for glaucoma and, potentially, other diseases.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A member of the G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily, cannabinoid type-1 receptor (CB1R), helps regulate diverse physiological processes in the central nervous system and periphery. Pharmacological CB1R modulation is therapeutically attractive as a potential means to address a variety of disease states and pathological conditions that represent important unsolved medical problems, including pain, cardiometabolic syndromes, substance-use disorders, and ocular conditions predisposing to vision loss.(1−7) Although the past several decades have witnessed the synthesis and pharmacological profiling of myriad designer CB1R orthosteric agonists and antagonists/inverse agonists with diverse chemical structures and biological profiles, their clinical application has been stymied by attendant psychiatric and behavioral side effects and the disrepute of some synthetic CB1R orthosteric agonists as notorious drugs of abuse.(8,9)
    Consequently, allosteric CB1R potentiation is gaining traction for translationally exploiting CB1R as a therapeutic target.(10−13) An allosteric modulator engages (a) site(s) on CB1R topologically distinct from the orthosteric site, where endogenous ligands bind and potentiates [positive allosteric modulator (PAM)] or attenuates [negative allosteric modulator (NAM)] orthosteric-ligand affinity/efficacy. In addition, allosteric modulators termed “allosteric agonists” exhibit intrinsic efficacy by virtue of which they directly regulate signaling pathways independent of orthosteric ligand by engaging (a) site(s) on the GPCR distinct from the orthosteric site. For realizing therapeutic gain through CB1R activation, application of the principles of allostery to design and synthesize small-molecule CB1R allosteric modulators leverages several potential advantages over typical CB1R orthosteric agonists that may translate into improved safety, efficacy, and overall pharmacological profile.(11,13−16)
    Along with allosterism, “biased agonism” or “functional selectivity” is another molecular-pharmacology feature that may be designed into GPCR ligands for optimizing their safety and/or efficacy as candidate drugs.(17−20) Compared to a “balanced” agonist, biased agonists acting at the same GPCR can elicit distinct cellular signaling profiles by preferentially stabilizing different active conformational states of the target receptor. Typically, CB1R exerts its biological effects by coupling to G proteins in Gi/o subfamily. Yet CB1R may signal through a variety of G protein-dependent and -independent pathways, with β-arrestin signaling paradigms being prominent among the latter.(21) The variety of ligand-dependent signaling effects exhibited by CB1R invites dedicated discovery of biased ligands that may direct CB1R-dependent information output preferentially along beneficial/therapeutic signaling pathways and away from others with more of an adverse-event risk.(22−27) This proposition has very recently met translational success upon the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulatory approval of the first GPCR biased agonist, the μ-opioid receptor agonist oliceridine {(R)-TRV130} (Trevena, Inc.; Chesterbrook, PA), as an analgesic.(28−30) Several other examples of biased ligands with preclinical safety and therapeutic efficacy attest to their therapeutic potential.(31) Although the concept of biased agonism was first introduced for orthosteric GPCR ligands, subsequent medicinal chemistry efforts have produced functionally selective allosteric ligands for pharmacotherapeutic exploitation.(32−34)
    Our drug-discovery efforts on the design, synthesis, and profiling of novel CB1R allosteric modulators as potential therapeutics led to the identification of enantiomers of the prototype CB1R ago-PAM, GAT211 (Figure 1), exhibiting enantiospecific allosteric CB1R modulation. As an ago-PAM, the resolved R-(+)-enantiomer (GAT228, 7) is a partial allosteric agonist able to directly activate CB1R, whereas the S-(−)-enantiomer (GAT229, 8) is a potent CB1R PAM and lacks GAT228’s intrinsic agonist activity (Figure 1).(35) The distinct molecular pharmacology of each GAT211 enantiomer demonstrates that the absolute stereochemistry of the benzylic center has a profound effect on ligand engagement and functional activity.(35,36) Both GAT228 and GAT229 showed signs of bias for G protein-dependent over β-arrestin2 signaling,(35) as they have two recently profiled ago-PAMs from this laboratory [GAT591 (5) and GAT593(6)].(37) Both racemic GAT211 and its enantiomers demonstrated preclinical analgesic efficacy and therapeutic activities against glaucoma and Huntington’s disease, all without apparent liabilities (i.e., tolerance, dependence, substance-abuse) associated with conventional CB1R orthosteric agonists.(38−45) The enantiospecific allosteric modulation of CB1R by GAT211(4) enantiomers and the attractive in vivo therapeutic profiles of these leads invites expansion of the structure–activity relationship (SAR) around this focused library of 2-phenylindole CB1R activators as detailed herein for optimizing their biological and physicochemical properties and defining the extent to which their pharmacological characteristics are tunable.(37,46) In this work, we have exploited the “magic methyl effect” involving tactical replacement of a hydrogen atom by a methyl group in the right place of the molecule, a frequently used strategy for improving potency/efficacy.(47−49)

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Ligand Design

    Our previous SAR studies demonstrated that the nitro functionality is a pharmacophore key to the CB1R PAM activity of the GAT211 scaffold. We further established that a chiral center on GAT211 has profound effects on activity and selectivity such that the two enantiomers generated (GAT228 and GAT229) display distinct molecular-pharmacology phenotypes and enantiospecific molecular-interaction profiles at CB1R.(35) Accordingly, we hypothesized that strategic installation of a methyl group at the α-position of the critical nitro functional group might be beneficial in terms of activity and functional selectivity, since this substitution creates an additional chiral center(50,51) and two diastereomers. The resultant family of four distinct enantiomers would allow interrogation of possible diastereomeric/enantiomeric interaction of these ligands with CB1R and the effect of the additional chiral center on (ago-)PAM activity (Figure 2).

    Chemistry

    To introduce a methyl group at the α-position of the −NO2 moiety, base-mediated enolization followed by quenching with methyl iodide was not successful. We next tried a classical Michael-addition approach. Treating 2-phenyl indole (11) with (E)-(2-nitroprop-1-en-1-yl)benzene (12) in the presence of CF3CO2NH4 under reflux yielded two Michael adducts, erythro stereoisomer, (±)-9 as the major product and threo isomer (±)-10 as the minor product (Scheme 1).(52) The reaction was readily scaled up to provide multigram quantities, and both diastereomers were separated by column chromatography followed by fractional crystallization. The structure of each diastereomer was characterized by 1H, 13C NMR, and high-resolution mass spectroscopy. In the 1H NMR of both diastereomers, the chemical shift (δ) value of the methyl group at the α-position to the nitro group of erythro-diastereomer, (±)-9, was at δ = 1.52 (doublet), whereas δ = 1.42 (doublet) for threo-diastereomer, (±)-10. The enantiomers of each diastereomer were separated by chiral superfluid column chromatography [(−)-13, (+)-14, (+)-15, (−)-16] at greater than 99% optical purity (see the Supporting Information). The absolute stereochemistry of each enantiomer was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). The absolute stereochemistry of (−)-13 is S,R; for (+)-14, R,S; for (+)-15, S,S; and for (−)-16, R,R (Figure 3).

    Structure–Activity Relationship (SAR) Studies

    The influence of methylation and chirality on GAT211’s biological activity as a PAM was indexed in vitro as CB1R-dependent inhibition of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) formation and β-arrestin2 recruitment in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO-K1) cells stably expressing human CB1R (hCB1R) with CP55,940 as orthosteric agonist (Table 1).(37) Cellular cAMP formation reflects G-protein-dependent adenylyl cyclase modulation, whereas β-arrestin2 recruitment reflects G protein-independent information pathways,(35) the two principal classes of signaling pathways for GPCRs, including CB1R.
    Table 1. hCB1R-Positive Allosteric Modulator (PAM) Activitiesa
    a

    PAM activity was quantified for cAMP inhibition using the DiscoveRx HitHunter assay in cells (CHO hCB1R) treated with EC20 (10 nM) CP55,940 + ligand for 30 min, and for β-arrestin2 recruitment using the DiscoveRx PathHunter assay in cells (CHO hCB1R) treated with EC20 (10 nM) CP55,940 + ligand for 90 min. Data were fit to a variable-slope (four-parameter) nonlinear regression model in GraphPad (v. 8.0.1). Data are mean with 95% confidence interval (CI) (EC50 values) or mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM; Emax values) for n = 2–3 independent experiments performed in duplicate. Statistical analyses were by nonoverlapping CI or two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey’s post hoc test. *p < 0.05 relative to GAT211 within assay; #p < 0.05 relative to (±)-9 within assay; @p < 0.05 relative to (±)-10 within assay; ∧p < 0.05 relative to cAMP assay within compound. Concentration–response curves are in Supporting Information Figure S1.

    The comprehensive in vitro SAR for the GAT211 congeners in these cell-based assays as derived from the concentration–response data in Supporting Information Figure S1 is given in Table 1. Compared to parent compound GAT211 (cAMP, EC50 = 230 nM, Emax = 110%; β-arrestin2, EC50 = 940 nM, Emax = 46%), methyl-substituted erythro diastereomer (±)-9 displayed greater potency as a PAM of cAMP inhibition and a trend toward greater efficacy as a PAM of β-arrestin2 recruitment (cAMP, EC50 = 15 nM, Emax = 110%; β-arrestin2, EC50 = 520 nM, Emax = 64%). (−)-(S,R)-13, one of the enantiomers of racemic (±)-9, was an equally potent but less efficacious PAM of CB1R-dependent cAMP inhibition (EC50 = 31 nM, Emax = 79%) with greater efficacy in the β-arrestin2 recruitment compared to the racemic (±)-9 (EC50 = 980 nM, Emax = 88%). The other enantiomer, (+)-(R,S)-14 was more efficacious than (±)-9 as a CB1R PAM of cAMP formation (cAMP, EC50 = 132 nM, Emax = 130%) and was inactive in the β-arrestin2 recruitment assay (EC50 = >10 000 nM, Emax = 0%). The other threo diastereomer (±)-10, was not significantly different from GAT211 in the cAMP inhibition assay (cAMP, EC50 = 120 nM, Emax = 94%), but less efficacious than GAT211 in the β-arrestin2 recruitment assay (EC50 = 2000 nM, Emax = 25%). The enantiomer (+)-(S,S)-15 obtained from diastereomer (±)-10 showed a trend toward improved potency with reduced efficacy as a CB1R PAM of cAMP inhibition (EC50 = 110 nM, Emax = 69%) with a slight difference in potency or efficacy for β-arrestin2 recruitment (EC50 = 790 nM, Emax = 30%) relative to the diastereomer (±)-10. The opposite enantiomer, (−)-(R,R)-16, displayed a trend toward reduced potency with reduced efficacy in the cAMP inhibition assay (EC50 = 610 nM, Emax = 67%) and was inactive in the β-arrestin2 recruitment assay (EC50 = 10 000 nM, Emax = 0%) relative to the diastereomer (±)-10. Similar to the parent compound GAT211, both diastereomers and all enantiomers did not exhibit any activity at CB2R in both cAMP and β-arrestin2 assays (data not shown). These data demonstrate that methyl substitution at the α-position of the −NO2 moiety has discrete influences on the signaling and molecular-pharmacology profiles of the prototypic 2-phenylindole ago-PAM, GAT211. The racemic diastereomers (±)-9 and (±)-10 display unique properties not specifically dependent upon one enantiomer or another, perhaps the result of combinatorial effects that are absent when only when enantiomer is tested. However, benzylic R-enantiomers (+)-(R,S)-14 and (−)-(R,R)-16 were devoid of β-arrestin2 activity, suggesting the stereochemistry at benzylic carbon is important for β-arrestin2 recruitment. Biological activity is maintained or enhanced, and ligand bias toward G protein-dependent vs -independent signaling can be augmented.

    In Vitro Biochemical Characterization: Orthosteric Radioligand Binding and G-Protein Activation

    By virtue of its PAM property, GAT211 increases the specific binding of orthosteric agonist [3H]CP55,940 to hCB1R in membranes isolated from CHO cells stably expressing this GPCR.(35) Compound (±)-9, its enantiomers (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14, as well as (+)-(S,S)-15 increased [3H]CP55,940 binding to hCB1R, whereas (±)-10 and its enantiomer (−)-(R,R)-16 marginally influenced [3H]CP55,940 binding at higher concentrations (Figure 4a,b, Table 2).
    Table 2. Effect of GAT Compounds on [3H]CP55,940 Binding to hCB1Ra
    compoundKi (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)
    (±)-9150 (88–250)74 ± 4.1
    (−)-(S,R)-1326 (7.3–91)55 ± 4.5
    (+)-(R,S)-14100 (30–260)39 ± 3.9
    (±)-10>10 000–19 ± 1.8
    (+)-(S,S)-15120 (34–330)36 ± 3.3
    (−)-(R,R)-16>10 000–34 ± 3.6
    a

    Effect of test compounds on [3H]CP55,940 binding was assessed in CHO cells stably expressing hCB1R. Data were fit to a variable slope (four-parameter) nonlinear regression model in GraphPad (v. 8.0.1). Data are mean with 95% confidence interval (CI) (Ki values) or mean ± SEM (Emax values) for n = 4–6 independent experiments performed in duplicate. Data were normalized to % CP55,940 bound without compound (0%). Radioligand binding curves are in Figure 4.

    The extent of G-protein activation following hCB1R agonist engagement (i.e., ligand efficacy) was quantified as binding of the nonhydrolyzable GTP analog, GTPγS, to the cognate Gi/o.(53) All compounds tested enhanced GTPγS binding in the absence of CP55,940, indicating that they possess intrinsic allosteric agonist activity (Figure 4c,d, Table 3). These compounds are termed as allosteric agonists as they have intrinsic agonist activity and at the same time, they do not compete with the orthosteric agonist binding. Among the compounds profiled, (±)-9 and its enantiomers, (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14, displayed greater efficacy than (±)-10 and its enantiomers. Compound (−)-(S,R)-13 was the most potent compound in the series with regard to GTPγS binding (Figure 4c,d, Table 3). Among all six compounds, (±)-9 and (−)-(R,R)-16 enhanced CP55,940-dependent GTPγS binding to the greatest extent, with (±)-9 doing so independently of CP55,940 concentration (Figure 4e,f, Table 3). The remaining four compounds, (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14, (±)-10, (+)-(S,S)-15, and (−)-(R,R)-16, enhanced GTPγS binding at 1 μM in combination with 0.1 or 1 nM CP55,940, but did not augment GTPγS binding in a CP55,940 concentration-dependent manner (Figure 4e,f). Collectively, these data support an SAR-driven correlation between CB1R-agonist and PAM activity/potency and modulation of orthosteric ligand binding, with (±)-9 and its enantiomers, (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14, displaying superior potency and efficacy. Similar to our observations in the preliminary DiscoveRx screen, these data support the conclusion that racemic (±)-9 displays pharmacological properties that are not intrinsically associated with its individual enantiomers. Rather the biological activity of (±)-9 appears in the assay examined to reflect the overall enantiomeric mixture, perhaps as a consequence of some functional influence between the two enantiomers therein.
    Table 3. Effect of Test Compounds on [35S]GTPγS Binding in the Absence or Presence of CP55,940a
     compound aloneCP55,940 + 1 μM compound
    compoundEC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)EC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)
    CP55,9401.6 (0.93–2.6)37 ± 1.4  
    (±)-9140 (85–230)69 ± 2.4n.c.69 ± 8.5***
    (−)-(S,R)-1325 (11–56)78 ± 3.5n.c.38 ± 2.3
    (+)-(R,S)-14170 (98–320)77 ± 3.1n.c.34 ± 6.4
    (±)-1063 (24–150)38 ± 2.3n.c.39 ± 5.3
    (+)-(S,S)-15140 (63–290)45 ± 2.9n.c.26 ± 2.8
    (−)-(R,R)-1675 (16–260)28 ± 3.11.3 (0.10–9.7)69 ± 4.6***
    a

    Effect of test compounds on [35S]GTPγS binding was assessed in CHO cells stably expressing hCB1R. Data were fit to a variable-slope (four-parameter) nonlinear regression model in GraphPad (v. 8.0.1). Data are means with 95% confidence interval (CI) (EC50 values) or mean ± SEM (Emax values) for n = 4–6 independent experiments performed in duplicate. Data were normalized to % stimulation over baseline. Concentration–response curves are in Figure 4. ***p < 0.001 Student’s two-tailed t-test, test compound vs CP55,940. n.c., not converged refers to concentration–response relationships in which EC50 could not be accurately calculated from data due to their shape.

    The diastereoselective nature of the interaction of (±)-9 vs (±)-10 with hCB1R, whereby (±)-9 was some eightfold more potent in the cAMP assay and fourfold more potent in the β-arrestin2 recruitment assay (Table 1) prompted extended biochemical and electrophysiological characterization of (±)-9 and its enantiomers, (−)-(S,R)-13 and (+)-(R,S)-14. Further profiling was also deemed compelling from the fact that (±)-9, (−)-(S,R)-13, and (+)-(R,S)-14 were all more potent and efficacious than the racemic parent, GAT211, with superior activity in biochemical assays of cAMP inhibition, β-arrestin2 recruitment and [3H]CP55,940 and GTPγS binding (Tables 1–3).

    In Vitro Cell-Based Characterization: Agonism, Signaling Bias, and Positive Allosteric Modulation

    To assess their potency, efficacy, and ligand bias as agonists and PAMs in G-protein-dependent (cAMP formation) and -independent (β-arrestin1 and β-arrestin2 recruitment) signal-transduction pathways, we evaluated (±)-9, (−)-(S,R)-13, and (+)-(R,S)-14 in another cell line (HEK293 cells) expressing CB1R. All three compounds produced a maximal response for inhibition of cAMP formation, acting as full allosteric agonists relative to the reference agonist, CP55,940 (Figure 5a). In the cellular cAMP assay, (±)-9, (−)-(S,R)-13, and (+)-(R,S)-14 were all more potent agonists than parent compound, GAT211 (Table 4).(35,37) Both (±)-9 and (−)-(S,R)-13 were weak partial agonists of β-arrestin1 and β-arrestin2 recruitment and did not differ significantly from the GAT211 (Figure 5b,c, Table 4) with more apparent efficacy at β-arrestin2 than β-arrestin1 recruitment (Figure 5c, Table 4). Notably, (+)-(R,S)-14 had no significant effect on β-arrestin1 and β-arrestin2 recruitment (Figure 5b,c).
    Table 4. Allosteric Agonist and PAM Activity of Lead Compoundsa
    inhibition of FSK-stimulated cAMP
     agonist modePAM mode
    compoundEC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)EC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)
    CP55, 94025 (17–36)100 ± 3.6  
    (±)-946 (31–67)90 ± 3.464 (34–120)84 ± 3.9
    (−)-(S,R)-1324 (14–40)93 ± 3.461 (18–81)90 ± 7.6
    (+)-(R,S)-14140 (88–210)91 ± 4.5210 (110–410)85 ± 5.8
    β-arrestin1 recruitment
     agonist modePAM mode
    compoundEC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)EC50 (nM)Emax (% CP55,940)
    CP55,940820 (520–1300)100 ± 6.8

    β-arrestin2 recruitment
